title: Women In This UP Village Don't Fast For Husbands On Karva Chauth Because Of An Age-Old 'Curse'
text:
Women In This UP Village Don't Fast For Husbands On Karva Chauth Because Of An Age-Old 'Curse'

Women In This UP Village Don't Fast For Husbands On Karva Chauth Because Of An Age-Old 'Curse'

Karva chauth is celebrated by women across north India. They observe a fast, pray for a long life for their husbands and then break the fast by looking at the moon.

While married women today will be observing the fast, there is one village in UP where women will not be fasting, incidentally, for the sake of their husbands' well-being.

According to legend, Mathura’s Vijau village has been dealing with a curse for the past 200 years. A Brahmin woman apparently cursed the entire community after her husband was killed by people on karva chauth. Since then, all the women in this village have avoided keeping fast on this day.

India TV

Village head, Murari Lal, also said that the widowed woman cursed the people of this village and killed herself by committing ‘Sati’ by sitting on her husband’s pyre. Since then, the women do not fast on this day, but they visit the ‘Sati temple’ for the long lives of their husbands.

Every male member also takes part in the rituals at the Sati temple. “We don’t even use sindoor given by our husband or their family but use our own," a 96-year-old from the Thakur family told TOI.

description: Karva Chauth is celebrated by women across North India, observing a fast and breaking it by looking at the moon for the safety and long lives of their husbands. It is a one day festival and is now celebrated in almost the whole country. While married women today will be observing the fast, there is one village in UP, where women will not be fasting, keeping their health in mind.
